Taboo Tattoo is one of those shows that starts with promise and then gets devastated by a poorly fitted pacing. The first few episodes set up a fun, if not hugely original, superpowers-and-conspiracy premise with more than enough material for 12 episodes, but gradually, and then faster and faster, it starts complicating things and rushing the exposition, frequently showing you things you have no hope of understanding and then slipping in the explanation for them later in a single line of dialogue or a flashback. If a good show sets you up with mysteries and anticipation, this one gives you FOMO - cause if youblink you're going to miss it.


By the end of one cour, the power levels have inflated 100-fold, every situation is fate-of-the-world-hangs-in-the-balance ungrounded in substance, and the running time is oversaturated with fight sequences. Characters enter, are seen doing things, and subsequently die with too little time for character development or understanding of their contributions to register. The cast is quite large and while it does manage to set up character relationships, they are tenuous. At times it feels like a PV of something that was more properly developed, with a lot of stuff happening set to music or voiceover.


And it's too bad. There is a lot of good material here that doesn't add up. The fights are well-made and can usually be followed pretty well. The detail of the animation only gets a little bit impacted towards the end, and there are a lot of cool character moments to be found. Some of the soundtrack, along with the setting's shadowy conspiracy and top-secret research, gave me a "Deus Ex" vibe. And it has a sprinkling of fanservice, which could have been done pretty well but like everything else is incredibly rushed, often being inserted directly into the middle of one of those high-stakes fight scenes.

I’m torn about this one. In the beginning, I understood that Taboo Tattoo was going to be cliched and predictable. But the were all the right cliches so I thought it would be a fun guilty pleasure. A bit of graphic violence, some fan service with a hint of comedy. and it was for the first eight episodes. But in the last four suddenly this incomprehensible story develops and Seiji’s one note character shifts from hero of justice fighting for what's right to...well, I’m not going to spoil it here. I’ll just say his character develops in a way that I thought was inconsistent withhis character (is it just me or does that sound redundant?). On the other hand, it’s nice to see characters having to change and grow with the situation they’re in. The art, character design and sound are good, so technically it’s a hit. But the story drowns in itself towards the end. Like it’s 24 episodes of material only greenlit for 12. So they completed the first eight episodes, skipped the next eight and compressed the rest into the last four. I hate to review anime by comparison but I’m reminded of Big Order (both were fanservice heavy and granted people powers with little explanation in order for them to battle one another), an anime I like FAR less than Taboo Tattoo, so it has to rate higher than that.  But was Taboo Tattoo really any good? If someone were to ask me should they watch it, I’d reply, “Only if you don’t have anything better to watch.” But is that fair? It’s not like it was promising anything more than it delivered. So I guess, it is what it is; average at it’s peak.

Taboo Tattoo was a pain for the eyes because of two main reasons: 
1 - The main character is nothing more and nothing less than a "tool". He is a mere device that aids people accomplish their tasks. Saying that he was used or manipulated would be too much of a praise. 
2 - I honestly don't know what they wanted to do with the story, but I know they seriously failed. Not only it progresses too fast, but the conclusions have no meaning and are barely satisfying.
This was labeled seinen, but it is more like a failed shounen. I have to praise the authorfor getting this pile of shit turned into an anime, honestly. The reason why they even considered making it into an anime is beyond me. \n\n
For anyone who wants to watch this anime, trust me, don't. This isn't worth wasting your time.
